landingPage.aboutUsContent: Klimatkollen is a citizen platform that provides climate data and builds support for reducing emissions in line with the Paris Agreement. We believe in the power of simple, engaging data visualisation to enhance knowledge and drive participation in the climate conversation.

municipalityRankings.title: Municipality Rankings

progressTracking.title: Progress Tracking

mission.heading: Our Mission
mission.paragraph: Klimatkollen exists to make climate data accessible to everyone. We believe that transparency drives accountability, and accountability drives real climate action. By putting emissions data in the hands of citizens, we empower communities to hold organizations accountable for their environmental commitments.

transparency.heading:
Why Data
Transparency Matters
transparency.paragraph: When emissions data is hidden behind corporate reports and paid databases, progress stagnates. Transparent, accessible climate data creates market pressure for better performance. Companies and municipalities that know their data is public work harder to improve their rankings and meet their climate commitments.

methodology.heading: Our Methodology
methodology.paragraph: We use emissions data from official reporting sources to create fair, comparable rankings. Our metrics focus on actual emissions reductions, not just promises or targets. Every ranking is based on real performance data, ensuring that climate leaders are recognized and climate laggards are held accountable.

impact.heading: Driving Real Impact
impact.paragraph: Our platform has already helped identify climate leaders and those falling behind across Sweden. By ranking organizations on their actual emissions performance, we create healthy competition that accelerates climate progress. The data doesn't lie—and neither should climate commitments.

engagement.heading:
Citizen Action &
Engagement
engagement.paragraph: Climate action isn't just for governments and corporations—it starts with informed citizens. When you can see how your local municipality or favorite company performs on climate metrics, you can make better choices as a consumer, voter, and community member. Your engagement drives the demand for better climate performance.

pathForward.heading: The Path Forward
pathForward.paragraph: Imagine a world where every organization's climate performance is as visible as their financial results. Where citizens can easily compare the environmental impact of their choices. Where transparency drives a race to the top in climate action. That's the future we're building, one data point at a time.

didYouKnow.title: Did You Know?
didYouKnow.subtitle: Interesting insights from Sweden's climate data - {{action}}!

header.title: About Us
header.description: Klimatkollen is a citizen platform that provides climate data. Click on the headings to learn more.

aboutPage.metaDescription: Learn about Klimatkollen and our mission to provide open climate data for citizens.

mainContent.title: What is Klimatkollen?
mainContent.paragraph1: Klimatkollen (eng, Climate Checker) is an open-source citizen platform that helps individuals, businesses and organisations track the climate transition by using Al to collect, analyse and spread key climate data.
mainContent.paragraph2: We provide a clear picture of how emissions are progressing compared to where they need to be. By making this information accessible, we empower the public, contribute to fact-based discussions, and strengthen support for climate action.
mainContent.paragraph3: Our vision is for decision-makers in politics and business to be guided by an informed and engaged public, leading to actions that reduce emissions in line with the Paris Agreement.
mainContent.paragraph4: Launched in March 2022, Klimatkollen is operated by the non-profit association Klimatbyrån. It was founded by Ola Spännar and Frida Berry Eklund. Initially focused on local climate data for Swedish municipalities, the platform expanded in 2024 to include corporate climate data.

ourApproachSection.title: Our Approach
ourApproachSection.paragraph1: Open climate data increases transparency and accountability. With climate data on hand, we can hold decision-makers in politics and business accountable for their promises to reduce emissions and fulfil the Paris Agreement.
ourApproachSection.paragraph2: Klimatkollen has developed Garbo AI for data collection and analysis. This enables us to present climate data for an increasing number of municipalities and companies, both in Sweden and internationally.
ourApproachSection.paragraph3: We do not claim to be flawless, this is brand new technology and tricky data even for those reporting it. But the more we test, develop and learn, the better Garbo AI and our data will become.
ourApproachSection.paragraph4: Klimatkollen complements the public sector. Authorities can – and should – only publish carefully processed data. This has many advantages. At the same time, the process can be slow, and correcting errors can take time.
ourApproachSection.paragraph5: We want to be faster. Wikipedia is updated daily by civil society. Klimatkollen works in the same spirit.
ourApproachSection.paragraph6: That is why we are grateful for feedback and suggestions. Do you see an error? Email us at <0>hej@klimatkollen.se</0> and we'll check it out and change.
ourApproachSection.paragraph7: Together, we make emissions data available to citizens. Everyone has the right to know how emissions are progressing and whether they are decreasing fast enough.

financingSection.title: How We Are Funded
financingSection.paragraph1: From November 2025 to the end of 2026, Klimatkollen will receive financial support from Postkodstiftelsen for the project 'AI for local climate influence'.
financingSection.paragraph2: In 2024 and 2025, Klimatkollen received financial support from Google.org as one of two Swedish recipients of the Google.org Impact Challenge: Tech for Social Good. This funding has allowed us to expand our corporate emissions data collection and analysis efforts.
financingSection.paragraph3: In 2023, Klimatkollen was funded by Postkodstiftelsen. Our 2022 launch was made possible through support from WWF Sweden, ClimateView, We Don't Have Time, and Argand Partners.
financingSection.paragraph4: Much of our work relies on voluntary efforts, and we welcome new partners and financial support to help us scale up!
financingSection.donate: Would you like to support our work?
financingSection.donateDescription: Every donation helps us expand and share more data.

previousProjectsSection.title: Previous Projects
previousProjectsSection.kommunprojektetDescription: In 2023, Klimatkollen received support from Postkodstiftelsen to evaluate the progress of the climate transition in municipalities. In addition to emissions data, we also highlight the actions municipalities are taking to reduce them by presenting key statistics on various transition areas.
previousProjectsSection.riksdagsvaletDescription: Before the 2022 parliamentary election, Klimatkollen was responsible for two unique projects:
previousProjectsSection.klimatmalText: An analysis of the political parties' climate goals for Sweden
previousProjectsSection.utslappsberakningText: A projection of how emissions would increase or decrease under each party's policies.

downloadsPage.title: Download Database
downloadsPage.description: Access our climate database. Download emissions data for companies or municipalities in your preferred format.
downloadsPage.csvDescription: Download the database as a CSV file, ideal for use in Python, R, Excel, or Google Sheets. All fields are comma-separated.
downloadsPage.excelDescription: Download the database in Excel (XLSX) format, perfect for analysis in Microsoft Excel or Google Sheets. All fields are preserved in spreadsheet structure.
downloadsPage.jsonDescription: Download the database in JSON format, ideal for developers and data analysis in tools like Python or R. Structured for easy parsing and programmatic access.
downloadsPage.downloadError: Failed to download file. Please try again.
downloadsPage.dataStructureDescription: All download formats share the same database structure, with consistent field names and data types. For details about individual fields, refer to our API documentation.

fileSizeAndFormatDescription.csv: CSV: UTF-8 encoded with comma-separated values. This is the smallest format and loads quickly in most spreadsheet tools. Ideal for general analysis and widely compatible with Excel, Google Sheets, Python, and R.
fileSizeAndFormatDescription.excel: Excel: XLSX format with multiple sheets. Slightly larger than CSV due to built-in formatting. Best for users who want a clean, structured spreadsheet view right away in Excel or Google Sheets.
fileSizeAndFormatDescription.json: JSON: UTF-8 encoded structured data. Tends to be the largest file due to detailed key-value formatting. Best for developers or analysts working with code, APIs, or automation in tools like Python or JavaScript.

downloadsPage.usageLicenseDescription: The downloaded data is licenced under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence (CC BY 4.0). You are free to use, modify, and share the data for both commercial and non-commercial purposes, as long as you credit Klimatkollen and include a link to the licence.

header.title: Sources and Method
header.description: Our starting point is the Paris Agreement's 1.5°C target, and all our data sources are publicly available. Click on the dropdown to learn more.

methodsPage.metaDescription: Learn about the methodology and data sources used by Klimatkollen to track emissions and climate transition.

dataSelector.label: Select what you want to learn about

parisAgreement.title: Klimatkollen and the Paris Agreement
parisAgreement.description: Learn about how Klimatkollen aligns with the Paris Agreement's climate goals
parisAgreement.paragraph1: The Paris Agreement is a legally binding international treaty between the world's nations, aimed at limiting global warming to well below 2°C, with a target of 1.5°C.
parisAgreement.paragraph2: To meet this target, global greenhouse gas emissions must be halved by 2030 (compared to 1990 levels) and reduced to near-zero by 2050. However, emissions are <0>still increasing</0> worldwide.
parisAgreement.paragraph3: Under the Paris Agreement, wealthier nations must take greater responsibility, as their historically high emissions mean they have already used a significant share of the remaining carbon budget needed to limit global warming. Sweden is among these countries and should lead the way in reducing emissions while also supporting more vulnerable nations in their transition.

link.title: Paris Agreement
link.text: Read more about the Paris Agreement on the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency's website.

carbonLaw.title: Carbon Law
carbonLaw.description: Understand how Klimatkollen applies Carbon Law to company and municipality data
carbonLaw.paragraph1: Carbon Law helps companies and governments to have a target for reducing their carbon emissions; it's a rule of thumb all entities of any size can use (world, country, company, municipality, individual, etc.). The original carbon law stated that emissions needed to be reduced by 7% per year starting in 2020, in other words, halving emissions every decade. It is based on the Paris Agreement's goal of limiting global warming to well below 2°C, with a target of 1.5°C and the carbon budgets identified by the IPCC.
carbonLaw.paragraph2: We use a revised version of the original Carbon Law to display a needed trajectory line on each company's or municipality's historic data graphs. This line shows the required emissions reduction for the company or municipality to stay in line with the Paris Agreement.
carbonLaw.paragraph3: A revised Carbon Law is necessary due to failure to meet the original carbon law's targets to reduce emissions by 7% per year starting in 2020. Taking into account the carbon budget as it now stands, a steeper trajectory is needed to meet the Paris Agreement's goal. The new rule of thumb is that emissions need to be reduced by 12% per year starting in 2025.
carbonLaw.paragraph4: Using the Carbon Law, we show the required emissions-reduction pathway on each company’s or municipality’s emissions-development graph. This “Paris Line” illustrates how much they need to reduce their emissions to align with the Paris Agreement.

link.title: Applying Carbon Law From 2025
link.text: Read more about the Applying Carbon Law From 2025 from Klimatkollen's white paper.

trendline.title: How We Calculate the Trendline
trendline.description: Learn about how we calculate the trendline
trendline.paragraph1: The trendline shows how an organisation’s emissions are expected to develop based on its historical data. It is not a forecast of planned climate action, but a statistical continuation of past behaviour.
trendline.paragraph2:
The trendline is used for two purposes:
1. To estimate missing recent years (for example if the latest reported data is from 2022 and we need values for 2023–2025).
2. To project emissions from 2025–2050 for Paris-alignment calculations.

whenCalculated.title: When a Trendline Is Calculated
whenCalculated.paragraph1: A trendline is only generated when there is enough valid historical data to make a meaningful projection.

companies.intro: For companies, we calculate a trendline only if:
companies.point1: at least three valid years of emissions data exist after filtering by base year,
companies.point2: we can identify a consistent emissions series (prioritising scope 3, otherwise scope 1 and 2), and
companies.point3: the remaining data after filtering is sufficient to compute a robust trend.

municipalities.point1: we use emissions from 2015 onwards, aligning with the start of the Paris Agreement period, and
municipalities.point2: we centre the regression on the last observed year to improve numerical stability.

whenCalculated.paragraph2: If an organisation does not meet these requirements, the trendline is not calculated and Paris alignment cannot be assessed.

whyLad.title: Why LAD (Least Absolute Deviations)?
whyLad.paragraph1: We use LAD (Least Absolute Deviations), or median regression, to make the trendline more robust and reliable.
whyLad.point1: LAD is less sensitive to extreme values than ordinary least squares.
whyLad.point2: It handles real-world volatility and jumps in climate data better.
whyLad.point3: It captures the long-term direction instead of reacting strongly to single-year spikes.
whyLad.point4: It produces a steady annual change in tonnes per year, rather than enforcing a fixed percentage.
whyLad.paragraph2: This aligns with our goal of capturing the underlying behaviour of emissions, rather than year-to-year noise.

howComputed.title: How the Trendline Is Computed
howComputed.paragraph1: The LAD trendline works by fitting a straight line through the historical emissions data, minimising the absolute difference to each year.
howComputed.step1: We identify usable historical emissions data (filtered by base year and scope logic for companies, or 2015 onwards for municipalities).
howComputed.step2: We centre the years around the last observed year to improve numerical stability and comparability.
howComputed.step3: We apply LAD/median regression to estimate the slope (change in tonnes per year).
howComputed.step4: We anchor the trendline to the last reported emissions value so the model connects smoothly to the latest real data.
howComputed.step5: We apply a zero floor so projected values never become negative.
howComputed.paragraph2: The final output is a slope in tonnes per year (for example −1,540 tonnes per year), indicating the expected annual change.
howComputed.paragraph3: We then use this slope to generate missing estimated years up to 2025 and to project emissions through to 2050. As new real data becomes available for future years, it replaces modelled values and the remaining future trend is recalculated from the updated historical record.

represents.title: What the Trendline Represents
represents.point1: a linear continuation of past behaviour,
represents.point2: a projection of absolute annual change (tonnes per year), not a fixed percentage,
represents.point3: an estimate of what future emissions might look like if no major changes occur, and
represents.point4: a necessary component for calculating total emissions from 2025–2050 for Paris alignment.
represents.notPoint1: a forecast of specific planned climate measures,
represents.notPoint2: a prediction that an organisation will comply with regulations or goals, or
represents.notPoint3: an endorsement of the organisation’s current pathway.
represents.paragraph3: It simply answers the question: “If this organisation continues as it has so far, what does its expected emissions pathway look like?”

whyWorks.title: Why a Linear Trendline Works for Paris Alignment
whyWorks.paragraph1: Paris alignment is based on total cumulative emissions from 2025–2050 — the organisation’s carbon budget for a 1.5°C pathway with around 50% probability.
whyWorks.point1: The linear trendline allows us to estimate whether the projected pathway stays within this carbon budget.
whyWorks.point2: If the trendline stays within the budget, emissions will necessarily approach very low levels well before 2050.
whyWorks.point3: Using the same method for all municipalities and companies enables fair, comparable assessments.
whyWorks.paragraph2: Even though a linear trendline does not mirror the exponential shape of the Carbon Law curve, it can still result in cumulative emissions that are lower than the Paris-aligned budget. In those cases, the organisation is considered to be on a Paris-aligned trajectory given its current trend.

parisAlignment.title: Paris Alignment
parisAlignment.description: Learn about how we calculate if a municipality or company is on track to meet the Paris Agreement

intro.paragraph1: “On Track for Paris Agreement” indicates that an organisation’s total projected emissions from 2025–2050 are compatible with a Paris-aligned carbon budget for around a 50% chance of limiting warming to 1.5°C.
intro.paragraph2: Rather than checking whether every year follows the exact –11.72% Paris Path, we evaluate the whole emissions pathway and ask: does this combination of past data and future trend stay within a fair carbon budget on the way towards net-zero around 2050?

carbonBudget.title: Carbon budgets and Paris alignment
carbonBudget.paragraph1: A carbon budget is the total amount of greenhouse gases that can be emitted over a given period while still keeping within a specific temperature target. In our case, we use Paris-aligned budgets that correspond to a 1.5°C pathway with roughly 50% probability.
carbonBudget.paragraph2: For each municipality or company, we construct a Paris-aligned carbon budget for the period 2025–2050. This budget is not a prediction of what will happen, but a benchmark that answers: how much can this actor emit on the way to net-zero if we want to stay within a 1.5°C pathway?

list1.item1: The budget is defined as the area under a Paris Path curve (Carbon Law) from 2025–2050.
list1.item2: The closer and earlier an actor brings its annual emissions towards (near) zero, the more likely it is to stay within this budget.

anchorYear.title: Anchor year and which data we use
anchorYear.paragraph1: We use 2025 as a common anchor year for comparing the Paris Path and the trendline projection. If the most recent measured emissions year is earlier than 2025, we estimate the 2025 value using the historical trend.
anchorYear.paragraph2: When new emissions data beyond 2025 becomes available, we always prioritise the measured values. The trendline is then used only to fill in missing and future years up to 2050. Over time, the assessment of Paris alignment is therefore driven more by real-world data and less by projections.

parisPath.title: Paris Path (Carbon Law)
parisPath.paragraph1: The Paris Path is based on the Carbon Law: an exponential reduction of emissions of about –11.72% per year. Starting from the 2025 anchor value, this creates a smooth, continuously declining pathway from 2025 to 2050.
parisPath.paragraph2: By integrating (summing) this Paris Path over 2025–2050, we obtain a Paris-aligned carbon budget for that actor. The Paris Path is therefore used as a reference trajectory that defines a budget, not as the only valid way to reduce emissions year by year.

trendline.title: Trendline projection (LAD)
trendline.paragraph1: To estimate how emissions may develop if current patterns continue, we use a linear trendline based on the Least Absolute Deviations (LAD) method. This trendline is calculated using the relevant historical data available for each actor.
trendline.paragraph2: The LAD trendline represents a steady change in tonnes per year, not a fixed percentage change. In practice, this means the same absolute reduction can correspond to smaller percentages when emissions are high and larger percentages when emissions are low.
trendline.paragraph3: For municipalities we typically use all available historical data that meet our quality criteria. For companies we may restrict the period (for example from a defined base year) so that the trendline reflects current operations rather than outdated business models. The details of how we calculate LAD are described in the trendline section of the methods page.

comparison.title: Comparing pathways and deciding “On Track for Paris”
comparison.paragraph1: Once we have both a Paris Path and a trendline projection anchored in 2025, we compare the total emissions from 2025–2050 along each pathway. In both cases we look at the cumulative emissions, i.e. the area under the curve over time.

list1.item1: The Paris-aligned carbon budget is the total emissions allowed along the Paris Path from 2025–2050.
list1.item2: The trendline total is the sum of measured emissions (for years where data exists) plus projected emissions from the trendline for missing and future years up to 2050.

comparison.paragraph2: If the trendline total is lower than the Paris-aligned carbon budget, we classify the actor as “On Track for Paris”. If the trendline total is higher than the budget, the actor is classified as “Not On Track”. Because the Paris budget is tight, a pathway that stays within it will almost always require emissions to approach very low levels or near-zero by 2050.

limitations.title: Limitations and interpretation
limitations.paragraph1: The trendline is not a forecast of planned measures, but a statistical extrapolation of recent behaviour. Real emissions may end up higher or lower depending on policy decisions, investments, technology changes and broader economic trends.
limitations.paragraph2: Our Paris alignment assessment focuses on the total emissions on the way towards net-zero, not on matching a specific percentage every year. It does not capture all aspects of fairness, responsibility or feasibility. It should therefore be interpreted as one important benchmark among several when evaluating whether an actor’s emissions pathway is compatible with the Paris Agreement.

interpretingOnTrack.title: How to Interpret “On Track for Paris”
interpretingOnTrack.description: Learn about how to interpret the “On Track for Paris” status
interpretingOnTrack.paragraph1: The Paris status on Klimatkollen is designed to answer a narrow but important question:
interpretingOnTrack.question: “If this organisation continues along its current path, will its total emissions from 2025–2050 fit within a Paris-aligned carbon budget and approach net zero in time?”
interpretingOnTrack.paragraph2: It is not a full judgement of all climate work, but a specific indicator based on reported emissions.

onTrack.title: On Track for Paris
onTrack.paragraph1: The organisation’s projected emissions pathway (trendline plus all available reported emissions data):
onTrack.point1: stays within the Paris-aligned carbon budget for 2025–2050, and
onTrack.point2: brings emissions close to zero well before 2050 if the trend continues.
onTrack.paragraph2: This means that, mathematically, the current rate of absolute reductions is sufficient to stay within a 1.5°C-aligned budget (50% chance) — assuming no major reversal in trend.

notOnTrack.title: Not On Track for Paris
notOnTrack.point1: exceed the Paris-aligned carbon budget for 2025–2050,
notOnTrack.point2: or do not fall fast enough to reasonably approach net zero in time.
notOnTrack.paragraph2: This does not mean the organisation is doing nothing, only that the current pace of reductions is too slow to be consistent with a Paris-aligned path.

noAssessment.title: No Assessment
noAssessment.point1: there is not enough reliable historical data to calculate a trendline, or
noAssessment.point2: the underlying data is too incomplete or inconsistent for a robust projection.
noAssessment.paragraph2: In these cases, we prefer transparency over a potentially misleading label.

scope.title: What This Indicator Does and Does Not Say
scope.paragraph1: The Paris status is a focused indicator. It tells you something important about the overall pathway, but it does not capture everything.

does.point1: focus on cumulative emissions between 2025 and 2050,
does.point2: use a consistent method across all municipalities and companies,
does.point3: provide a simple, comparable signal of whether the current path fits within a 1.5°C-aligned budget.

doesNot.point1: guarantee that the organisation will actually implement future measures,
doesNot.point2: assess all climate policies, investments, or adaptation work,
doesNot.point3: include consumption-based emissions or indirect effects beyond the chosen scope,
doesNot.point4: reflect every source of uncertainty in future projections.

scope.paragraph2: In other words, it is a useful, comparable climate signal, but not the whole story.

changes.title: Why the Status Can Change Over Time
changes.paragraph1: The Paris assessment can change when:
changes.point1: new historical emissions data is reported,
changes.point2: a stronger or weaker trend emerges in the updated data,
changes.point3: reporting scopes or base years change for companies,
changes.paragraph2: As more 2025+ real data becomes available, modelled trend years are gradually replaced by actual emissions, and the assessment becomes more tightly anchored in observed reality. For a detailed description of the underlying calculations, see Section 3: “How We Calculate ‘On Track for Paris’” and Section 4: “How We Calculate the Trendline”.

historicVsParis.title: Historic % Change, Paris Path and Paris Alignment
historicVsParis.paragraph1: Klimatkollen shows several different metrics that are easy to confuse: the historic % change, the Paris Path (Carbon Law) and the “On Track for Paris” indicator. They are related, but they describe different parts of the story.
historicVsParis.paragraph2: The historic % change describes how fast emissions have changed on average during a past period (for example 2015–2023). The Paris Path describes an idealised exponential reduction rate (–11.72% per year) that would, if followed exactly, lead to a Paris-aligned emissions pathway. The “On Track for Paris” indicator instead focuses on the total cumulative emissions from 2025–2050 compared to a Paris-aligned carbon budget.
historicVsParis.paragraph3: Because the trendline is based on absolute tonnes per year, the implied % changes are small when emissions are high and naturally become steeper as emissions fall. This means that a modest historic % change can still be compatible with a future pathway where cumulative emissions stay within the Paris-aligned budget.
historicVsParis.paragraph4: In other words: a low historic % does not automatically mean “off track”, and a high historic % does not automatically mean “on track”. What ultimately matters for Paris alignment is whether the entire expected emissions pathway from 2025–2050 fits within the available carbon budget. For an intuitive explanation, see the data guide analogies linked from the emissions graph.

emissionTypes.title: Different Types of Emissions
emissionTypes.description: Learn about the various types of emissions and how they are measured
emissionTypes.paragraph1: Klimatkollen is an independent fact-based platform that follows established standards for emissions reporting. The climate data we present reflects the boundaries and assumptions used in carbon budget calculations. For example, carbon budgets cannot be directly linked to all greenhouse gas emissions, as other gases like methane, nitrous oxide, and water vapour are also included in overall climate impact assessments.
emissionTypes.paragraph2: Emissions from cement production are excluded from the IPCC's global carbon budget and, as a result, are also omitted from Sweden's carbon budget and emissions data. This specifically affects the municipalities of Gotland, Skövde, and Mörbylånga, where cement production is currently or has previously taken place.
emissionTypes.paragraph3: Sweden also has a significant climate impact from goods imported from other countries, leading to emissions abroad. These consumption-based emissions are not included in the carbon budget.
emissionTypes.paragraph4: Similarly, emissions from forests and land (known as biogenic emissions) are also excluded from the carbon budget.
emissionTypes.paragraph5: In reality, climate-impacting emissions are much higher than the territorial fossil carbon emissions typically reported by authorities and the media. The data currently displayed on Klimatkollen reflects these territorial emissions.
emissionTypes.paragraph6: Klimatkollen is actively exploring how to incorporate other greenhouse gas emissions on the website in the future, while maintaining the ability to compare current emissions with carbon budgets.

companyDataOverview.title: Company Data Overview
companyDataOverview.description: Overview of how we collect and present company emissions data
companyDataOverview.paragraph1: Klimatkollen collects data on greenhouse gas emissions that companies report in their sustainability reports and combined annual reports.
companyDataOverview.paragraph2: Different companies may use different methods to calculate their emissions. Sometimes they also state that certain data refer to a year other than the year in which they are reported. Klimatkollen takes a citizen's perspective and therefore show the data that is publicly disclosed in the latest annual report. This is also a prerequisite for being able to compare companies more fairly. Read more about each company's calculation method in their report, which we link to from the companies' pages.
companyDataOverview.paragraph3: The emissions data is divided into company-specific emissions (scope 1 & scope 2) and emissions from the value chain (scope 3), reported in tonnes of CO2e.
companyDataOverview.paragraph4: On each company's page on Klimatkollen, you can find more detailed information about the emissions; breakdown by scope and category in scope 3, as well as any biogenic emissions.

link1.title: Klimatkollen's Company Data
link1.text: View our latest company emissions data here

link2.title: GHG Protocol
link2.text: Klimatkollen uses the same structure as the GHG Protocol and follows its guidelines.

companiesIncluded.title: Companies Included
companiesIncluded.paragraph1: Currently, our database includes companies on the OMX Large Cap and Mid Cap lists of the Stockholm Stock Exchange, along with the 24 largest state-owned companies, five largest economic associations, and unlisted companies IKEA and ICA Group.
companiesIncluded.paragraph2: The companies are categorized by industry according to the Global Industry Classification Standard (GICS), with a total of 290 companies currently tracked.

link.title: GICS
link.text: Read more about the Global Industry Classification Standard (GICS)

companyDataOverview.paragraph5: Information about the number of employees and revenue is obtained from the latest sustainability reports, or combined annual and sustainability reports, and in some cases from other sources.

companyDataCollection.title: Data Collection Process
companyDataCollection.description: Learn about our methodology for collecting and verifying company data
companyDataCollection.paragraph1: We present companies' greenhouse gas emissions as they report them, with data divided into company-specific emissions (scope 1 & 2) and value chain emissions (scope 3).
companyDataCollection.paragraph2: In some cases, our figures may be more up-to-date than company reports due to direct communication with companies about data corrections.
companyDataCollection.paragraph3: While we strive for accuracy, Klimatkollen does not take responsibility for the completeness or accuracy of company reports.
companyDataCollection.paragraph4: Emissions are rounded to the nearest whole number, which may cause minor variations from company reports.
companyDataCollection.paragraph5: The description of the company's activities is AI-generated.

dataPresented.title: Data Presentation
dataPresented.paragraph1: Emissions data is presented as reported by companies, with clear categorization of different emission scopes.

fiscalYear.title: Fiscal Year Reporting
fiscalYear.paragraph1: Some companies use a fiscal year. In these cases, the emissions are presented for the later of the two calendar years in the period, i.e. for companies that report 2022/2023, the data is presented for 2023.

historicalData.title: Historical Data and Goals
historicalData.description: Tracking companies' emission history and climate commitments

historicEmissions.title: Historical Emissions
historicEmissions.paragraph1: Emissions data from previous years has been collected from the latest report, to the extent it is presented there. Where there are gaps in the reported emissions data, for example if there is missing information about emissions for years between the base year and the most recently reported year, Klimatkollen has sought to collect this by searching for older sustainability reports. The latest published information is always prioritized, so if a company has updated its calculations retroactively, but not published the adjustment, older data may be displayed.

goals.title: Climate Goals
goals.paragraph1: AI-tool Garbo identifies and extracts goals and initiatives for emission reductions that companies describe in their reporting. This data is not manually verified.

emissionCategories.title: Emissions and Categories
emissionCategories.description: Understanding different types of emissions and how they are categorized
emissionCategories.paragraph1: Companies report their emissions according to the GHG Protocol's three scopes:

scope2.title: Scope 2: Indirect Energy Emissions
scope2.paragraph1: Scope 2 emissions are primarily calculated using the market-based method, which takes into account whether companies purchase renewable electricity. If such data is missing, we use data from the location-based method instead.

scope3.title: Scope 3: Value Chain Emissions
scope3.paragraph1: Value chain emissions are reported according to GHG Protocol categories when available.
scope3.paragraph2: When a total value is missing for scope 3, we sum the figures for the disclosed scope 3 categories.
scope3.paragraph3: When companies report emissions per category in line with the GHG Protocol, the data is presented directly on the company's page. For companies that use other breakdowns, Klimatkollen makes a judgment about the match with the GHG Protocol. Companies that, for example, combine several categories into 'other', or report upstream and downstream transport as a single category, do not have their scope 3 emissions broken down per category.

link.title: Reporting of Emissions in Scope 3 for Property Owners
link.text: For property owners, Klimatkollen follows the matching as specified in the guied Reporting of Emissions in Scope 3 for Property Owners.

financedEmissions.title: Financed Emissions: Scope 3 Category 15: Investments
financedEmissions.paragraph1: Financed emissions are often reported with a delay, as they are often based on the previous year's data from the companies included in the investment. We show emissions data in scope 3 category 15 in the year it is publicly reported in the annual report, even if it is sometimes stated that the data in this category comes from a previous year.

biogenicEmissions.title: Biogenic Emissions
biogenicEmissions.paragraph1: Biogenic emissions are reported separately from scope 1, 2 and 3, in accordance with the GHG Protocol's instructions.

emissionOffsets.title: Emission Offsets
emissionOffsets.paragraph1: These are not included, in line with what the GHG Protocol states.

relatableNumbers.title: Relatable Numbers
relatableNumbers.description: Learn more about how we put the numbers into context.
relatableNumbers.paragraph1: Emission numbers can be difficult to grasp, so we’ve translated changes in emissions over time into more relatable terms. This helps illustrate how much an increase or decrease in emissions really means.
relatableNumbers.paragraph2: Rather than comparing total emissions, we focus on the change — for example, how much a company or region’s emissions have gone up or down compared to the previous year.

forestFire.title: Forest Fires
forestFire.paragraph1: We have calculated how large a wild fire would have to be to  produce the same amount of emissions. We base this on the following data:
forestFire.paragraph2: Based on the emissions change, we calculate how many hectares equals that amount of CO₂. This is then compared to familiar references such as football fields, tennis courts, or city areas. Using this method, we can express it as something like: “This amount of CO₂ corresponds to emissions from a wild fire as large as X football fields”.
forestFire.bullet1: On average, each hectare of forest contains about 50 tons of carbon (C). (1)
forestFire.bullet2: Carbon is converted to carbon dioxide (CO₂) using the factor 44/12 (molecular weights), which means that one hectare corresponds to roughly 50 × (44/12) ≈ 183 tons of CO₂.

citizens.title: Citizens
citizens.paragraph: To make the emissions change easier to understand, we compare it to the average annual conspumtion based greenhouse gas emissions per person per year. In our case, we assume that an average person accounts for 9 tons of CO₂-equivalents (tCO₂e) per year. (2)

municipalityDataOverview.title: Municipality Data Overview
municipalityDataOverview.description: What data we collect and present about the municipalities
municipalityDataOverview.paragraph1: Klimatkollen shows emissions data on Sweden's municipalities, with SMHI's national emissions database as our primary source. To make our municipal and company data comparable, emissions of all greenhouse gases (CO₂e) are shown since August 2025, not just CO₂.
municipalityDataOverview.paragraph2: We also show how emissions would need to decrease to meet the Paris Agreement. Previously, this was based on local carbon budgets derived from a national budget calculated by researchers at Uppsala University and the Tyndall Centre in the UK. Since August 2025, we have switched to use the 'Paris Curve' based on an updated <0>Carbon Law</0>.
municipalityDataOverview.paragraph3: The forecast for future emissions is based on how emissions in each municipality have developed historically since the Paris Agreement in 2015. The trend line is weighted using the statistical method Least Absolute Deviations (LAD), which gives less weight to individual extreme values and provides a more fair and realistic picture of future emissions. You can read more about our emissions calculations <0>here</0>.
municipalityDataOverview.paragraph4: Alongside emissions data, Klimatkollen presents key indicators of municipal performance in the energy transition and emissions reductions, such as growth with EVs and bicycle lanes.

municipalityKPIs.title: Municipality KPIs
municipalityKPIs.description: What data we collect and present about the municipalities
municipalityKPIs.paragraph1: In addition to showing whether emissions are on track with the Paris Agreement, we also present data on the progress of different transition measures in the municipalities.
municipalityKPIs.paragraph2: We have based our criteria on municipal responsibility, impact on emissions, breadth of areas, and access to stable data. So far, using these criteria, we have presented data on the following key figures:

list.evs: Electric vehicles - The increase in the municipalities for the proportion of newly registered electric vehicles
list.consumption: Consumption - The household's consumption emissions in tonnes per resident and municipality
list.chargers: Chargers - The number of electric vehicles per public charging point per municipality
list.bicycles: Bicycles - Metres of cycling paths per resident, per municipality
list.plans: Plans - Which municipalities have an ongoing climate action plan
list.procurements: Procurements - Which municipalities have placed climate requirements in public procurement

sources.title: Our Sources
sources.description: Explore the publicly available sources and verified data used by Klimatkollen
sources.paragraph1: Klimatkollen is based on publicly available sources and verified data. We provide all sources so you can easily review and explore them further. If you notice any errors, please email us at hej@klimatkollen.se so we can make corrections.
sources.paragraph2: Company data is sourced from their own annual reports and sustainability reports.

content.header: Become a Supporting Company – Stand Up for Open Climate Data
intro: By publishing open climate data, Klimatkollen promotes transparency and strengthens support for the Paris Agreement in both politics and business. Without knowing how emissions are progressing – and how they should be – we cannot take the necessary actions to reduce them effectively.
Klimatkollen is a data-driven non-profit organization building a movement around open climate data.
We collaborate with businesses, academia, and civil society to maximize impact. AI, open data, broad communication, and citizen engagement are at the core of our approach.
Join the movement for open climate data – become a supporting company today!
content.benefitsHeader: As a supporting company, you will receive:
benefits: Your commitment highlighted with our logo on your website
Visibility among other corporate supporters on our website
Notifications when new data about your company is published
Automatic updates of your climate data to your company’s Wikipedia page

contact.title: Contact Us
contact.description: Have questions about supporting Klimatkollen, or want to find other ways to volunteer? We'd love to hear from you.

municipalityDetailPage.reductionToMeetParis: Emission reduction to meet the Paris Agreement

scope.scope1: Direct emissions from sources owned or controlled by the organisation.
scope.scope2: Indirect emissions from the production of purchased electricity, steam, heat, and cooling consumed by the organisation.
scope.scope3: Indirect emissions from the organisation's value chain, including suppliers and customers.
scope.biogenic: Biogenic emissions refer to carbon dioxide emissions from non-fossil (i.e., renewable) sources, such as the combustion of biofuels or by-products from paper production. Under the GHG Protocol, these emissions are reported separately from Scope 1–3, as they are part of the natural carbon cycle.

ola.description: Opinion leader, co-founder of Klimatkollen, former communications manager at the Centre Party, and client manager at Forsman & Bodenfors.

frida.description: Climate specialist and co-founder of Klimatkollen. Initiator of Our Kids' Climate and author of the book 'Talking to Children about Climate Change' (Natur & Kultur). EU Climate Pact Ambassador and Climate Reality Leader.

elvira.description: Tech lead and technical physicist at Klimatkollen and Precisit. Extensive experience in green and circular tech at several award-winning startups and part of the leadership team at IT consultancy firm Precisit.

christian.description: Award-winning developer, digital entrepreneur, and one of Sweden's most influential figures in tech. Founder of the digital innovation agency Iteam and co-founder of Open School Platform. Speaker on AI and digital innovation, advisor to the government.

kayla.description: Frontend developer with a passion for sustainability and user-friendly digital solutions. Previously worked as an environmental consultant focused on interpreting regulations and calculating greenhouse gas emissions for companies.

catharina.description: Communicator and filmmaker focusing on climate and sustainability, active in organisation Ett hållbart Lidingö, with a background as a management consultant.

elin.description: AI and backend developer focused on creating reliable and production-ready AI solutions. Background in both consulting and research. Working with Klimatkollen to make climate data accessible through AI.

carl.description: Frontend developer who loves nature, climbing, and creating tools that make climate data easier to understand. Supports Klimatkollen's volunteers, develops the frontend, and tries to find the perfect GIFs for every occasion.

myvi.description: Data Analyst specializing in automating data workflows and transforming raw data into actionable insights and visualisations. Formerly at Telia, AVL, KPMG, Vinnova and Assistant Professor in mathematical engineering physics at Bharath Institute Of Science And Technology in Chennai, India.

ola.description: Opinion leader, co-founder of Klimatkollen, former communications manager at the Centre Party, and client manager at Forsman & Bodenfors.

frida.description: Climate specialist and co-founder of Klimatkollen. Initiator of Our Kids' Climate and author of the book 'Talking to Children about Climate Change' (Natur & Kultur). EU Climate Pact Ambassador and Climate Reality Leader.

maria.description: Journalist, author, speaker, and founder of Klimatklubben. Named one of Sweden's 101 most influential sustainability figures in 2021.

carlJohan.description: Sustainability strategist at Diamant & Schulz, previously at Doings and Forsman & Bodenfors, author of the book 'Sustainability Transformation', awarded Marketing Book of the Year 2022.

madeleine.description: Responsible for solar parks within Green Power Sweden, former head of social policy for WWF Sweden, board member of the Swedish Society for Nature Conservation and political expert at the Ministry of the Environment.

emissionsBreakdown.title: Emission Breakdown {{year}}
emissionsBreakdown.tooltip: Breakdown of emissions by different scopes according to the GHG Protocol

1.name: Purchased goods and services
1.description: Emissions from the production of goods and services purchased by the organisation.

2.name: Capital goods
2.description: Emissions from the production of capital goods purchased by the organisation.

3.name: Fuel- and energy-related activities
3.description: Emissions from the production of fuels and energy purchased by the organisation, including transport and distribution, not included in scope 2.

4.name: Upstream transportation and distribution
4.description: Emissions from the transport and distribution of purchased goods between suppliers and/or within the organisation.

5.name: Waste generated in operations
5.description: Emissions from the treatment of waste generated by the organisation.

6.name: Business travel
6.description: Emissions from business travel using vehicles not owned by the organisation.

7.name: Employee commuting
7.description: Emissions from employees' travel between home and workplace.

8.name: Upstream leased assets
8.description: Emissions from operations in leased assets not included in scope 1 and 2.

9.name: Downstream transportation and distribution
9.description: Emissions from the transport and distribution of sold goods between the organisation and the customer.

10.name: Processing of sold products
10.description: Emissions from further processing of sold input materials.

11.name: Use of sold products
11.description: Emissions from the use of sold products by the customer.

12.name: End-of-life treatment of sold products
12.description: Emissions from waste treatment of sold products at the end of their lifecycle.

13.name: Downstream leased assets
13.description: Emissions from operations in downstream leased assets not included in scope 1 and 2.

14.name: Franchises
14.description: Emissions from franchisee operations not included in scope 1 and 2.

15.name: Investments
15.description: Emissions from the organisation's investments in other companies, as well as other financed emissions.

16.name: Other
16.description: Reported emissions not tied to one of the scope 3 categories.

card.emissionsChangeRateInfo: Change rate of emissions compared to the previous reporting period.
card.emissionsChangeRateInfoExtended: This value is so large due to inconsistencies in reported data between the last two reporting periods, thus this value is not representative of actual changes.
card.meetsParis: Is {{name}} on track to meet the Paris Agreement?

emissionsHistory.title: Emissions development
emissionsHistory.tooltip: Showing the development of reported emissions over time; click on a point to remove the line from the graph. Hover over a point to see the values for the reporting period.
emissionsHistory.baseYearInfo: The base year refers to a specific year chosen as a reference point against which future emissions are compared.
emissionsHistory.scope3: Scope 3 - Attributed Supply Chain and Product Lifecycle Emissions
emissionsHistory.trendInfo: Approximated value is based on average change of {{percentage}} since {{baseYear}} for all reporting periods
emissionsHistory.exploreStep0Description: This shows emissions data from before the company's base year. While historically interesting, this data is often unreliable for predicting future trends because companies were still developing their measurement methods and may have used different reporting standards.
emissionsHistory.exploreStep1Description: This shows the company's emissions from their base year to the most recent reporting period. This data is considered reliable and comparable because the company has established measurement methods and consistent reporting standards.
emissionsHistory.exploreStep2Description: This shows our best estimate of how the company's emissions might change in the future, based on their recent performance. We calculate this trend carefully, but it's important to note that predicting emissions is challenging - companies often have few data points and emissions can vary significantly from year to year.
emissionsHistory.exploreStep3Description: This green line shows the emissions reduction path needed to meet the Paris Agreement goals. The target is to reduce emissions by about 11.7% each year, which means roughly halving emissions every 5-6 years. This is the global standard for climate action.
emissionsHistory.exploreStep4Description: This step shows where the company's trend line and the Paris target path end up in 2050. While a company might only be slightly above or below target in 2050, the next step will show why the cumulative impact over many years is what really matters.
emissionsHistory.exploreStep5Description: This step reveals the true story: it's not just about where we end up in 2050, but about the total emissions over the entire journey. Think of it like a bank account - small differences in spending each month add up to big differences over years. The shaded areas show the total emissions 'debt' or 'savings' compared to the Paris target.
emissionsHistory.trendExplanationFallback: This trend line shows our best estimate of future emissions based on the company's recent performance. We use statistical methods to calculate this, but predictions become less certain the further into the future we look.
emissionsHistory.parisAlignedPathLabel: Estimated Emissions For Paris Aligned Path
emissionsHistory.totalEmissionsSaved: total emissions saved vs Paris target
emissionsHistory.totalEmissionsExcess: total emissions excess vs Paris target

overview.financialsTooltip: Financed emissions are often reported with a delay, as they are often based on the previous year's data from the companies included in the investment. We show emissions data in scope 3 category 15 in the year it is publicly reported in the annual report, even if it is sometimes stated that the data in this category comes from a previous year.

electricCarChangePercent.detailedDescription: The growth rate in municipalities for the share of newly registered rechargeable cars 2015-2024, stated in percentage points per year.

totalConsumptionEmission.label: Consumption
totalConsumptionEmission.detailedDescription: Household consumption emissions (CO₂e) in tonnes per inhabitant and municipality in 2022. By 2050, emissions should be at most 1 tonne per person per year to be in line with the Paris Agreement.
totalConsumptionEmission.source: Stockholm Environment Institute (2025), Konsumtionskompassen. Licensed under CC BY-NC-ND 4.0.

electricVehiclePerChargePoints.label: Charging Stations
electricVehiclePerChargePoints.description: Number of electric vehicles per charging point
electricVehiclePerChargePoints.detailedDescription: Number of electric vehicles per public charging point, per municipality in 2024. Lower numbers are better, as good infrastructure promotes increased electric vehicle adoption.

bicycleMetrePerCapita.label: Bicycles
bicycleMetrePerCapita.detailedDescription: Number of metres of bicycle paths per inhabitant per municipality in 2024. Longer is better, as good infrastructure promotes increased cycling.

privacyPage.seoDescription: Read about how Klimatkollen processes personal data and protects your privacy.
privacyPage.seoText: Klimatkollen values your personal privacy and complies with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).
privacyPage.title: How Klimatkollen Processes Personal Data
privacyPage.responsibilityText: Klimatbyrån with organisation number 802537-8814 is the data controller when the organisation processes personal data.
privacyPage.dataCollectionText: The personal data we collect is primarily information that you provide yourself (name, address, mobile number, etc.) when, for example, you sign up for our newsletter or become a member. You may also be employed by a partner or other contact of Klimatbyrån, in which case the personal data is your contact information at work.
privacyPage.whyTitle: Why do we process personal data?
privacyPage.whyText1: We process the data to fulfil the commitments associated with the purpose stated at the time of collection or for the collaboration. Otherwise, we use your information only for purposes related to Klimatbyrån's own activities. We do not share your information with third parties.
privacyPage.whyText2: Klimatbyrån values personal integrity. Handling personal data correctly and securely is a priority for us. Those who entrust us with their information should feel secure.
privacyPage.whyText3: We comply with the General Data Protection Regulation and other laws and regulations in the data protection area. You always have the right to request correction or deletion of your personal data.
privacyPage.contactText1: If you have questions or requests regarding the handling of your personal data, please contact us.

learnMorePage.title: Global Emissions
learnMorePage.subtitle: Why tracking, reporting and transparency of emissions is critical to enacting tangible change.
learnMorePage.impactDescription: Each particle represents millions of tons of CO₂ emissions. Watch as they accumulate over time, demonstrating the exponential growth of global emissions since the industrial revolution.
learnMorePage.impactDescription2: The visualisation above shows how emissions have increased dramatically since 1950, with particularly rapid growth in recent decades.
learnMorePage.trackingDescription: We cannot effectively reduce what is not measured. Accurate emissions tracking is the foundation for meaningful climate action.
learnMorePage.companiesDescription: Corporate emissions make up a significant portion of global carbon output. Accurate tracking enables businesses to identify reduction opportunities.
learnMorePage.communitiesDescription: Local communities need to understand their carbon footprint to implement effective reduction strategies and sustainable practices.
learnMorePage.countriesDescription: National emissions data are critical for setting and achieving climate goals, and holding countries accountable to their commitments.
learnMorePage.dataGapsDescription: Missing or inaccurate emissions data hinders our ability to make informed decisions and take effective climate action.
learnMorePage.whyTrackingMattersDescription: Comprehensive emissions tracking is essential for:
trackingBenefits: Identifying the most effective reduction strategies
Facilitating informed policy and regulatory decisions
learnMorePage.csrdDescription: The EU's Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) represents a significant step forward towards standardized and comprehensive emissionsreporting.
learnMorePage.currentChallengesDescription1: Inconsistent methodologies across companies and regions
learnMorePage.currentChallengesDescription4: Difficulty tracking progress towards Paris Agreement goals
learnMorePage.csrdImprovementsDescription1: Standardized reporting requirements across the EU
learnMorePage.csrdImprovementsDescription4: Digital tagging for improved data accessibility and transparency
learnMorePage.parisAlignmentDescription: CSRD helps track progress towards Paris Agreement goals by:
implementationSteps: 2025: Large companies that have not yet reported
2026: Large-cap listed SMEs and other companies
Gradual expansion to cover more businesses

searchDialog.title: Search
searchDialog.emptyText: Start typing to search for companies or municipalities

trendAnalysis.insufficientData: No trendline shown due to insufficient data ({{dataPoints}} points). Need at least 2 data points to build reliable trend.
trendAnalysis.insufficientDataSinceBaseYear: No trendline shown due to insufficient data since base year {{baseYear}} ({{dataPoints}} usable points). Need at least 2 data points since base year to build reliable trend.
